# The Area-Based Approach (ABA) to forest modelling

Here we provide an example domstration on how to process ALS point cloud data to create wall-to-wall predictions of selected forest stand attributes using an area-based approach (ABA) to forest inventories. The steps used in this vignette as well as further details about enhanced forest inventories (EFI) are described in depth in [White et al. 2013](https://cfs.nrcan.gc.ca/publications?id=34887) and [White et al. 2017](https://cfs.nrcan.gc.ca/publications?id=38945). 

This vignette assumes that the user has a directory of classified and normalized `.las/.laz` files. 


### Load necessary packages

```r
library(lidR)
library(sf)
```

### Read in data

The function `catalog` builds a `LAScatalog` object from a folder. `LAScatalog` objects produce regions of interest (ROIs) from each ALS file within the `catalog` directory. Make sure the ALS files have associated index files - for details see: [Speed-up the computations on a LAScatalog](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/lidR/vignettes/lidR-computation-speed-LAScatalog.html).

```r
ctg <- catalog("F:\\petawawa\\ALS_Petawawa\\ALS2012\\ALS2012_norm_nobuff_filtered")
# See details of the catalog object
ctg
```

```r
plots <- st_read("PRF_plots.shp")
```

We have now prepared both our ALS and plot inventory data and can begin ABA processing.



# ABA Processing

### Step 1 - Configure the catalog 
Set `opt_output_files` option to write the results on disc. This is an important option to set. The clipped plots will be saved on hdd and not kept in memory. We also use the `opt_filter` function to ignore noise below 0 m so that they do not influence future processing.

```r
# Write files to disc
opt_output_files(ctg) <- paste0(tempdir(), "/{PlotID}")
# Ignore points with elevations less than 0
opt_filter(ctg) <- "-drop_z_below 0"
```

### Step 2 - Clip ALS point cloud using `lasclip`  
Note that the `radius` parameter is 14.1 because our plot radius is 14.1 m. This step may take a while.

```r
# Clip catalog object using plots with a circular buffer of 14.1 m
plots_ALS_clipped <- lasclip(ctg, plots, radius=14.1)
```

The `plots_ALS_clipped` object is now a `LAScatalog` object containing all clipped plots.

```
plots_ALS_clipped
```

```r

extent      : 299037.3 , 314863.4 , 5089938 , 5098440 (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax)
coord. ref. : +proj=utm +zone=18 +ellps=GRS80 +towgs84=0,0,0,0,0,0,0 +units=m +no_defs 
area        : 160376.5 m²
points      : 1.67 million points
density     : 10.4 points/m²
num. files  : 203 
```

### Step 3 - Calculate plot metrics
We first set some processing options using `opt_chunk_buffer` and `opt_chunk_size`. Setting these options to 0 mean that there will be no buffer around our plots when we calculate metrics and that processing will not be done in chunks (we do this for plots because they are small and do not require chunk processing functionality). We also use `opt_output_files` to have plot metrics stored in memory instead of on disc.

```r
opt_chunk_buffer(plots_ALS_clipped) <- 0
opt_chunk_size(plots_ALS_clipped) <- 0
opt_output_files(plots_ALS_clipped) <- ""
```

To calculate metrics for each plot we use the `catalog_apply` functionality. We specify that we want to process our `plots_ALS_clipped` catalog object using `lasmetrics` to calculate all metrics contained in the `.stdmetrics_z` function. The `func` argument also supports user defined functions. The output of `catalog_apply` is a list of vectors (`plots_metrics`), which we convert into a `data.table`.
```r
plots_metrics <- catalog_apply(plots_ALS_clipped, lasmetrics, func = .stdmetrics_z)
plots_metrics <- data.table::rbindlist(plots_metrics)
```


We have now calculated a variety of ALS metrics for each plot. In order to complete our inventory and begin modelling we now must merge ALS metrics with field measured values (`D`). 
```r
D <- cbind(as.data.frame(plots), plots_metrics)
```

### Step 4 - Modeling
Here we provide a simple example of how to create an OLS model (`lm`) for Lorey's Mean Height (HL). Using the `summary` and `plot` functions we found that the 85<sup>th</sup> percentile of height (`zq85`) for ALS metrics explain a large amount of variation in `HL` values. We are more than happy with this simple model.

```
m <- lm(HL ~zq85, data=D)
summary(m)
```

### Step 5 - Wall to wall modelling
Now that we have created a model using plot data, we now need to apply that model across our entire study area. 

To do so we first need to generate the same suite of ALS metrics (`.stdmetrics_z`) for our ALS data using the `grid_metrics` function on our original `ctg ` `LAScatalog` object . We have chosen to write these metrics into memory. Note that the `res` parameter is set to 25 because we want the resolution of our metrics to match the area of our sample plots (14.1 m radius ≈ 625m<sup>2</sup>).

```r
opt_output_files(ctg) <- ""
metrics_w2w <- grid_metrics(ctg, .stdmetrics_z, res = 25)
```

To visualize any of the metrics you can use the `plot` function.

```
plot(metrics_w2w$zq85)
plot(metrics_w2w$zmean)
plot(metrics_w2w$pzabovezmean)
```



### Step 6 - Calculate wall-to-wall predictions

We can use two methods for applying our model (`m`) to all of our ALS data. We can do this manually using the model coefficients, or use the `predict` function. Both of these methods produce the same output (`HL_pred`) which is a wall-to-wall raster of predicted Lorey's mean height.

```r
HL_pred <- coef(m)[1] + metrics_w2w$zq85 * coef(m)[2]
# Or
HL_pred <- predict(metrics_w2w$zq85, m)
```

To visualize wall-to-wall predictions use

```
plot(HL_pred)
```

![](images/ABA/06_HL_pred.png)

</center>
